direction.raw_text: Then stay away, chutiye, and count your blessings every morning you open them and see the sun rising. You owe Maman. He doesn't forget.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I owe Latika. Arvind shakes his head angrily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please. Is she alive? Arvind, is she alive?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alive? Oh, she's alive alright. It's your life, Jamal. Pila Street. They call her Cherry, now. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 96   CONTINUED: (3)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you. Jamal heads off through the traffic. Arvind shouts after him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I will sing at your funeral, yaar. 97   EXT. PILA STREET. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm looking for Cherry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, kid. Not available. Plenty of others. Take a look. She indicates curtained cubicles behind him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm Latika's brother. The Woman looks at him properly for the first time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's still not on the menu. Choose someone else or piss off. Then, Jamal pulls out some rupee notes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just two minutes to talk to her. She takes the money, counts it. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 98    CONTINUED:                                                    98 WOMAN Two minutes. She nods upwards. Salim and Jamal head up the dark, tiny staircase. The Woman picks up the phone on her desk. 99    INT. LANDING. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On the tiny landing, Salim and Jamal pull back a curtain to reveal a humping couple. They move on, past more women lying on their beds or blankly having sex, not in the least perturbed to be interrupted. They reach the end of the landing. From the other side of the door comes the filmi music. Jamal puts his eye to one of the gaps in the slatted door. Through it he can see glimpses of a girl dancing to the music. Latika; though not the rag-picker of before. Now fifteen, she is a beautiful young woman and dressed in a revealing, turquoise, silk sari.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is it her or not? He shoves Jamal out of the way and watches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shit, she's sexy, man.... Then the music stops, an effeminate man steps into the limited frame Salim can see and snaps a stick down hard on Latika's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Smile! Flow, flow! You entice with the hands not make chapattis, you gawaar. Again. The man starts the music again and Latika's hands flow elegantly around her head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lift your feet, you lump. Stop, stop! The stick is raised to hit her but Jamal opens the door. 100   INT. BROTHEL. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She can barely believe her eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jamal? The Dance Teacher turns. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 100   CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What the hell do you want? He switches off the music.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come. Quick. But Latika remains fixed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You silly little boys. Get out now while you can.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come with us. Latika runs to Jamal. But she freezes as she looks at the doorway. Maman, Punnoose and the Woman from downstairs stand there. The skin around Punnoose's eye bears the blisters from the chloroform burn years ago.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look who we have here, Punnoose. Hello again, Jamal. Salim. Never forget a face. Especially one that I own.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shall I take them to the marshes?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whatever you like. Have fun. Just make sure that you dispose of them properly afterwards. No traces, thank you. He turns to Jamal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You really thought you could just walk in and take my prize away? Have you any idea how much this little virgin is worth, bhen chod? He fingers Latika's hair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get them out of here. Punnoose and the Muscle walk towards Jamal. Maman turns to the Dance Teacher as they grab his arms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please continue, Master-ji. The Dance Teacher puts the music back on. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 100   CONTINUED: (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Suddenly, Salim is holding a pistol.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leave him. Get over there. Punnoose and the Muscle slowly release Jamal and join Maman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's not be foolish, Salim. Heavy, aren't they? Salim straightens up his gun arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can have money. Here. Maman gets out his wallet and throws all the money in it on the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take it. Go. Disappear with your friend and we'll forget all about this. Okay? Salim collects up the money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maman never forgets. Isn't that right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, Maman can make an exception. Salim walks over to the music, turns it up. Picks up a cushion from the bed and walks right up to Maman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can't take that risk, Maman. Sorry. He wraps the cushion around the gun and pulls the trigger. Or tries to. Nothing happens. There is a frozen moment as they watch him fail to shoot. Everybody watches with surreal interest as Salim fumbles with the pistol. Eventually he looks up, giggles stupidly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Safety catch. Shrugs apologetically and shoots. Nobody is more surprised than Maman who crumples onto the floor. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 100   CONTINUED: (3)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Latika starts desperately gathering up the notes on the floor, grabs Maman's wallet. Jamal just stands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on. They run out of the room and down the stairs as Maman dies on the floor in front of his frozen colleagues. 101   EXT. CHOWPATTY BEACH. DUSK.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Children are splashing in the sea, flying kites, digging sand, laughing. Salim, Latika and Jamal are crouched on the shore watching the sun sink into the sea. Latika is going through Maman's wallet, Salim is fingering the pistol, admiringly. Jamal is staring out to sea. Each in their own world, yet sharing swigs from a bottle of Johnny Walker.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shit, there's thousands here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We should be celebrating.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You just killed somebody.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He was going to kill us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where did you get the gun?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bought it. Now, I'm going to have to throw this beauty in the sea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You didn't need to kill him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What? Typical. I save your life and you're on at me. All you ever do is mess us up. Whenever you're around-
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - shut up, can't you? Just shut up. Silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why can't you just be happy, huh? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 101    CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She takes a long swig from the bottle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She nudges Jamal and holds the bottle out to him. Smiles at him. He smiles back, shakes the black dog from his head and takes a long, long drink. Latika and Salim cheer. 101A   EXT. TULIP STAR. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Latika, Salim and Jamal bend back a bit of the wire mesh fence that protects the deserted hotel. Crawl in. 102    INT. TULIP STAR. LOBBY. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A very wobbly Latika, Salim and Jamal walk up the frozen escalators of the empty hotel, lit only by security lights. Kick through the odd pile of rubbish and stacked-up chairs. Go to the dusty reception desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And they scoot off, giggling into the dark. 102A   INT. TULIP STAR. KITCHENS. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jamal and Latika wander the vast, empty kitchens. Jamal searches the empty chillers and cabinets. Then, realises that he is alone. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 102A   CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where are they? Suddenly,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She comes shooting out of the darkness across the kitchen floor riding a trolley with Salim pushing her at top speed. Jamal has to skid out of the way. He grabs another trolley and glides off in pursuit. 102B   INT. TULIP STAR. CORRIDOR. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The three stand by a mirror and play with their reflections. 102C   INT. TULIP STAR. HOTEL LOBBY. LATER.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On top of the metal preparation counters, Salim and Jamal are fencing: Jamal with a fish slice and Salim with a large spoon. 103    INT. HOTEL ROOM. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An empty, dusty hotel suite. Jamal is on the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jamal closes his eyes at the wonderful thought.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She stops. Change of mind. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 103   CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pop Tarts!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hold the line, chutiye. Pop Tarts?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On the tv. The commercial. Everybody's happy when they have Pop Tarts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Exactly! A bucket of Pop Tarts, chutiye. Jamal slams down the phone. 104   INT. HOTEL ROOM. LATER.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Latika is clearly in the shower. Jamal wanders in carrying an old pair of lunghi. Shouts through the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Found some lunghi!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stay there. Look away. The shower stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Atcha, atcha.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll know if you're looking....
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not! With a towel around her, Latika comes to the doorway where Jamal is holding out a the lunghi with his eyes tight shut.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where's Salim?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dunno. She watches this innocent a second with true fondness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're a sweet boy, Jamal. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 104   CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She takes the lunghi from his outstretched hand and disappears into the bathroom, slamming the door with a giggle. 105   EXT. MUMBAI SLUM STREET. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Salim wanders the crowded streets of a slum. He stops uncertainly at a doorway where a group of men are lolling, smoking. Plucks up his courage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm looking for Javed-bhai.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ja, mada chod. He's not looking for you. Ja!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I need to see him. The group of men stir, irritated now. Salim begins to back away, then stops. Pulls the gun from behind his back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I killed Maman. I'll kill you too. Easy. The group are frozen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You killed him? Javed is standing in the doorway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My enemy's enemy is my friend, no? So, come in, friend. 106   INT. HOTEL ROOM. LATER.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jamal and Latika lie on the bed, drunk, though still coherent. Latika is dressed in the Bell-Boy's jacket and the old lunghi.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maman's gang will hunt us. You know that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't care.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Me neither. They burst into stupid laughter. The laughter subsides. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 106   CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That dance you were doing. In Pila Street. Show me. Latika rolls over and switches off the light. Rolls back. In the half light, her hands begin to move for Jamal, the elegant, alluring hand movements of the bar- girl dancers. Jamal stares, mesmerised.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You came back for me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought you'd forgotten.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I never forgot. Not for one day. I knew I'd find you in the end. It's our destiny.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Destiny. Yes. Latika stops her hands. They stare at each other, their faces inches away from each other. Latika strokes Jamal's face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you. And face to face, they slowly fall asleep. 107   INT. HOTEL ROOM. LATER.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey. Jamal opens his eyes. Salim is standing over them, swaying with alcohol.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Salim? He puts his hand out to Latika.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Salim....Bhai, you've had a lot to drink... Jamal tries to get up, but Salim's hand is round his throat and pushes him down on the bed. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 107   CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am the elder. And I am the boss. For once, you do as I say.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Salim pulls Latika to her feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I saved your bloody life, didn't I?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Salim, please-
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - chup, sali. As he turns, pulling a protesting Latika, Jamal leaps on him. The two brothers go down fighting, but of course it is Salim who comes up on top. Latika launches herself at Salim, but he smashes her away, almost delighted that she has joined in. He drags Jamal to the door, laughing. 108   INT. HOTEL CORRIDOR. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Salim throws him out into the corridor, slams the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am Number One now!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Salim, no, no....!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get yourself a room, bhai. Salim slams the door. Jamal gets up, bangs on the door, keeps on banging until the door opens and Salim stands there with the pistol pointing straight at Jamal's head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The man with the Colt 45 says chup. He shoves Jamal hard down the corridor, the gun pointed at him all the while.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Salim... Salim nods towards the fire escape door. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 108   CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now go. Or Gunmaster G-9 will shoot you right between the eyes. Boom. Don't think he won't. You have five seconds. One, two, three, four- Salim cocks the pistol. Jamal screws up his eyes for the inevitable. But Salim shoves him out with a roar and slams the door. Jamal bangs on the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Salim... Salim walks slowly back down the corridor as Jamal bangs and bangs on the door. Down the hall, Salim's door shuts. 109   INT. INSPECTOR'S OFFICE. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Inspector is staring hard at Jamal. Srinivas is desperately trying to get his attention.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir, sir!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Enlighten us Constable.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Accessory to murder, Sir. The Inspector puts his hands in the air, palms up. Simple.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Only the finest minds in the Mumbai Police Force. Untroubled by irony, Srinivas looks extremely pleased.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go check the files, Constable. Srinivas goes out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You puzzle me, Slumdog. Admitting murder to avoid a charge of fraud is not exactly clever thinking. Now, why would you do that? Jamal shrugs. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 109   CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When somebody asks me a question, I tell them the answer. 110   EXT. TULIP STAR. MORNING.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At the gate, a Security Guard is sitting in his chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where are they? The Guard grunts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where did they go? A more impatient grunt from the Guard. He stands up, walks towards Jamal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please, Sir. Which way?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know and I don't care. The Guard raises his stick and gives him a roar. Jamal backs away onto the street. The Guard slams the gate shut. Jamal looks despairingly up and down the street at the teeming traffic, the crowds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ready for another question.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. I'm ready. 111   OMITTED                                                  111 112   INT. STUDIO. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We are back in the Studio.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For two and a half million rupees. Ladies and Gentlemen. Cambridge Circus is in which UK City. Is it A) Oxford, B) Leeds, C) Cambridge, D) London. Jamal smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's smiling. Why does that worry me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 113   EXT. MUMBAI. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leaden skies. Torrential rain is hammering on the tin roofs of the slum. 114   INT. SHACK. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eighteen year-old Jamal's eyes open. Now with the beginnings of a beard and moustache, Jamal wakes in a tiny shack just big enough for a mattress on the floor. He pulls on a shirt, lifts the mattress and takes out his trousers which have been pressing there all night, puts them over his shoulder, picks up his shoes and goes down a ladder. 115   INT. SHACK. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He descends into a room and two feet of water that is eddying around the ground floor of the shack. Wades out of the door into the narrow lane of the slum. 116   EXT. SLUM. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jamal nods hello to a number of neighbours, also bare- legged, also with their shoes in hand. Together, they wade to higher ground, put on their trousers and shoes and trudge up to the main road. 117   INT. CALL CENTRE. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ultra-modern, glass-windowed office. The words Cultural Studies are written on the white board. Jamal walks in with a tray of glasses of chi. He puts a glass down on the young, hip, Teacher's desk and heads out again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, guys, it's been a big week in UK. Kat is back. He holds up a copy of Radio Times showing Kat from East Enders smiling at them. A collective groan from the Trainees.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's already back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bardi...Jamal?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh. Well. She did come back, then she went away when Alfie split up with her and now she's back again. (MORE) (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 117   CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But it looks as if Alfie still fancies Mo after all, so-
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - thank you, Jamal. Keep up, Bardi. The chi-wallah knows more than you. Bardi glares at Jamal. Jamal shrugs apologetically and goes out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, it's been super-duper hot for UK this week, so there'll be a lot of chat about that- they love their weather- and there's the festival in Edinburgh- Edinburgh? He points at a young woman Trainee.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Scotland. Kilts, castles, err, haggis? Porridge, the Highlands, mountains. Ben- Ben Nevis? The Teacher points at another Trainee.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Detective Taggart. Whisky, Sean Connery!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And lochs. Their word for lakes. Good. It's also double bonus time for an upgrade to the `friends and family' package this week, so remember to push for an upgrade...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Every Call! Jamal walks out, turns a corner. 118   INT. CALL CENTRE. UK FLOOR. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We are confronted with a room you could swing a Boeing in. Rows and rows of Operators in tiny booths stretch into the distance. On the walls are pictures of London, Tony Blair, red telephone boxes, the Yorkshire Dales, the Highlands- a snapshot of tourist Britain. Huge posters of soap stars and celebrities adorn the rest of the walls. Slogans hang from the ceiling. "When the sun comes up, you'd better be running", "you snooze, you lose", "Upgrade for a better, faster life." "Every call is a new opportunity". (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 118   CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Each section of the room has a banner with a British city's name on it and various mock sign-posts for the different aisles. A Manager under the banner "Bradford", is standing over an Operator, listening in on a call. The Manager leans over and presses a key.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If they want an upgrade, a new tariff or we're stealing them from the other networks, you take the call. Anything else- He mimes cutting his throat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No time-wasters on Team Bradford, kid. Leave that to the homosexuals on Tunbridge Wells. Jamal stops by him. The Manager takes a glass of tea from Jamal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where've you been? Dave on Cornmarket's virtually lost his voice, there's two on Ilkley Moor who've had their hands up for hours. Come on, move it! Jamal hurries down the aisle signposted "Cornmarket", gets to a male trainee and hands him a tea. Dave glances around to check nobody's looking and slips off his head-set.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two minutes, Jamal. I'm on "Millionaire" duty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rajneesh...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's my turn, Jamal. I've had my pee breaks. Please. If he comes just keep your head down and pretend you're doing an upgrade on the-
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - `friends and family'. I know. Jamal still looks unwilling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two minutes. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 118   CONTINUED: (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dave heads off towards a Rest and Recreation room, where a big plasma screen on the wall is showing "Who Wants To Be A Millionaire."Jamal grabs the jacket from the back of Dave's chair, puts the head-set on and hunches over the booth, just another Operative at work. We become aware that every operator down the Cornmarket aisle- and quite a few other aisles besides- is staring in the direction of the Rest and Recreation Room. 119   INT. REST AND RECREATION ROOM. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...we are back in the studio, the gun-fire morphing into rapturous applause. (CONTINUED)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The studio lights have seamlessly transformed into the harsh bulb of an interrogation light. Jamal is strung from the ceiling by his arms.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...on the set of Who Wants to be a Millionaire. Prem leans back in his chair, a man at home in his surroundings. Jamal sits opposite, frozen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We look up from the bottom of the bucket at the screaming face of a drowning man. His head shakes desperately, pointlessly. Then Jamal's face is dragged up again, roaring for breath. Close on his eyes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jamal's body dangles motionless from the ceiling. His head is bowed and he is moaning to himself. The ceiling fan thumps round slowly. In the corner, Constable Srinivas mops his brow and lights a cigarette. Hot work. The door opens and the Inspector of Police walks in. A rumpled man in his late forties who has seen pretty much everything. He eyes Jamal, surprised.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: An excited Young Police Constable sticks his head around the door.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bright sunlight filtered through the ever-present Mumbai dust. A group of children are playing cricket on a tarmac cricket ground. They are bare-foot, dressed in little more than rags, wiry-skinny and fast on their feet. Salim, a nine-year old, polishes the ball on his almost non-existent shorts, comes in with surprising speed and bowls. The batsman hooks it high in the air. The bowler screams at a boy in the outfield.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He pays no heed to the rest of the children who are scattering fast to the edges of the tarmac. The ball seems suspended in the blue sky. Shouts from the other children seem very far away. He doesn't notice that they are screaming for him to get out of the way. Jamal adjusts his feet for the perfect catch. Then out of nowhere, a light aircraft almost takes his head off as it comes in to land on the tarmac runway. Jamal is knocked to his feet by the down-draft of the plane. The ball bounces away. Also flattened, Salim gets to his feet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: At the back of a pack of children, carrying a piece of wood crudely fashioned into a sword, Jamal is running for his life, pursued by an ancient but surprisingly nimble Security Guard from the airport who is screaming abuse and wielding a long stick. The kids dash across a rubbish dump and disappear down dozens of tiny lanes that run in between the shacks of the slum.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The lanes in between the corrugated iron shacks are three feet wide, with an open drain running down the middle. Many of the precarious upper floors of the shacks have been built right over the paths, turning them into black tunnels. Tunnels shot through with slivers of light. If you didn't live here, you would be lost and frightened in minutes. But these children are natives and with the practice of many years, Jamal and Salim zig-zag down the warren of lanes. They dodge past people cooking in the doorways, sleeping, washing clothes or in the case of Vinod, a naked four year-old, pissing into the drain. Salim shouts a warning. (CONTINUED)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The two renegades are dumped by Jamal's Mother into their desks as Mister Nandha hands out ancient school books.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ... in the Inspector's office. Jamal watches Srinivas fiddling with the video recorder, trying to get a picture. Through the pebbled glass, Jamal sees shapes moving along the corridor. 16   INT. CORRIDOR. POLICE STATION. DAY.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Commissioner of Police is fawning along beside Prem as they walk. The Young Constable hurries behind.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Srinivas has finally got the recorder to work. We get snatches of filmi dancing- heroines singing on mountainsides surrounded by implausible numbers of flags- cricket and finally after some shouting by the Inspector, Who Wants to Be A Millionaire?.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...as Prem asks the first question.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A tiny shack. A garland of dirty plastic flowers surrounds a torn flyer for one of Amitabh Bacchan's films. 20   EXT. JUHU SLUM. RUBBISH DUMP. NIGHT.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Salim is sitting on a chair at the end of a rickety wooden pier, though it is not water, but a sea of rubbish and sewage that lies below them. There are dozens of these piers protruding from the slum onto airport land, each with a toilet shack perched right at the end. Another man hurries up the pier and hands Salim a coin.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: .S. (singing/ grunting)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jamal peers through one of the many cracks in the shack. He sees crowds surging around the pier, charging towards a landing helicopter. Salim shoves the chair under the door handle- effectively locking it- and runs down the pier to join the chase. Jamal pulls up his shorts.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Rattles the locked door. Pulls a torn flyer from his pocket advertising an Amitabh movie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: From high up, the rickety tin roof-tops of the slum seem to stretch to the horizon. There is a distant shout, a figure waving an arm.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (singing)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not far away, Salim wanders to Mister Chi's stall. He glances around to make sure everybody is glued to the hindi film on Mister Chi's tv and surreptitiously slips Mister Chi the signed flyer. Mister Chi takes a look and gives Salim a small wad of rupees. He sticks the money in his pocket, slinks away. 24   EXT. JUHU SLUM. NIGHT.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A tear-stained Jamal is furiously trying to batter Salim, but Salim's extra strength and height means that he can keep Jamal at bay with one hand, Jamal's flailing fists punching thin air.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Close on the tv screen in the Inspector's office. Prem ponders Jamal's choice. Presses a button on his computer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (squealing)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (startled)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Inspector presses pause. Sighs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (can't help himself)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (amused)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Director is shaking his head.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Right next to the railway lines is a pond of dirty water surrounded by shacks in which dozens of women are washing clothes. Trains flash past only feet away from them. Down the other end of the pond, nine-year old Jamal and Salim are splashing noisily with some other children. Jamal's mother pauses in her scrubbing, wipes sweat from her forehead and gazes up at the leaden sky.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She has two bleeding red gashes on her back. They turn a corner and head towards some vans full of police. Jamal sees Mister Nandha, the school teacher, stops.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They reach the safety of the police vans. But inside the vans, the police are smoking, laughing, playing cards. Down the street, a man comes whirling out of a doorway, his hair on fire. He falls into the middle of the street and is engulfed by rioters. Unperturbed, the police continue to chat. Salim and Jamal look on, horrified. Then one of the police men turns, looks at them. Is interested. Motions to a colleague. Puts out his cigarette with purpose.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Salim and Jamal stand on a hill overlooking the city. Black smoke billows from a large area that is clearly the Juhu slum. Standing a little way off is the girl.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No answer. Jamal sits down. Salim sits down. At a distance, the girl sits down. Rain pours down their faces. 34   INT. BUILDER'S YARD. NIGHT.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Rain as you've never seen. A pile of huge water pipes in a sprawling builder's yard. Jamal is in one pipe, Salim above him in another. They are both soaked, shivering, but have found some plastic sheet to wrap themselves in. Outside, thirty feet away, stands the girl. Staring. Salim hisses angrily at the girl.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jamal wakes with a jolt and a scream half-swallowed in his mouth. He shuts his eyes tight, trying to force the image out. His breathing slows and he sees the girl staring at him. Salim, too, is staring into nothing. The rain is still falling. (CONTINUED)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The girl goes back to drawing shapes in the mud with her finger. Jamal climbs out of the pipe. Looks at Salim for permission or refusal, but he just continues to stare. So, Jamal walks across to her. She looks up, wary.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jamal looks at the Inspector.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The lights dim, the music swells.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In the half-light, backstage, Nita dabs his face with powder.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Prem slings himself in a chair.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (furious)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He sits back down, says almost to himself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Known to everyone as VT station, this monument to Victorian railway architecture is a dangerous place to be at rush hour. (CONTINUED)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Even before the train has stopped, men are jumping from the open doors, or vaulting out of the windows or from the roof of the train to join the tens of thousands of Mumbaites streaming to and from work. A seventeen-year old Jamal squeezes himself out of a train and shoves through the crowds. He checks the time. The digital numerals flick to five O'clock. Looks around the tide of humanity. 42   INT. STUDIO. NIGHT.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The digital clocks show five fifteen. Shoving the descending river of people out of his way, the eighteen year-old Jamal is forging a path up steps that cross the platforms. He pushes to the middle of the footbridge and leans out on the side railings. He scans the sea of people, desperately. Then he sees her: the eighteen year-old Latika, heart-stoppingly beautiful, over the other side of the station. A world away. She is scanning the crowd, as wired as he is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The commuters have mostly gone. Jamal is pacing the platform desperately. He stops, stares blankly at the statue in front of him- a proud, rather pompous figure in a Victorian frock coat. The plaque reads: Frederick Stevens.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Inspector, Srinivas and Jamal are staring at the video recorder.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jamal is studying a piece of paper and reading out numbers from it. There is something not quite right about Jamal- perhaps the fact that there are two feet by his ears. Salim is standing on his shoulders and spraying the numbers on a wall with an aerosol and a certain lack of confidence. (CONTINUED)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (whispered)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They charge across the lawn, down one side of the house where all the washing is hanging. The Guard gets caught up in drying sheets, towels. He fights his way through to see Salim, Latika and Jamal leaping over the wall to safety. But Jamal turns, jumps back and grabs a girl's dress from the line.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jamal is examing the bruises on his legs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (infuriated)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Blazing sun. Diggers and trucks are shifting mounds of rubble on a rubbish dump that seems to stretch for ever. Oblivious to the dust kicked up by the trucks, Latika is picking up old plastic bags, examining each one and putting the less worn in a big sack. The dress is recognisable but dusty and torn. She stoops to dig another bag out of the dirt, but stops and stares. Shimmering in the heat, a rickety pick-up truck comes through the rubbish dump gates. Toots at the Guard who waves, pulls up in the dump. "Hope Orphanage is written on the side of the van. A man gets out. Looks around. 53   INT. `TENT'. DAY.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Under sheets of plastic propped up on sticks, Jamal and Salim are sleeping out the hottest part of the day. Jamal wakes to see a figure standing over him- a silhouette with a halo of sun behind him. Out of his bag, the man produces a bottle of Thumbs Up. He uncaps it with an alluring hiss. It is almost an advert for thirst-quenching affluence. Almost instinctively, Salim and Jamal stir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The hills on the edge of Bombay. Greenery and space, for the first time in the film. The pick-up truck pulls up outside a building with Jamal, Salim and Latika sitting on a bench in the back. Maman gets out. Drops the gate on the back of the pick-up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Twenty children are eating at long benches in a ramshackle courtyard. Maman, ushers Jamal, Salim and Latika in and sits them down at one of the benches. He waves a hand and a giant man, Punnoose, comes over with a big bowl of food. The three tear into it. Cleaning every last morsel of rice from his plate, Jamal looks up and notices a table peopled entirely with blind or crippled children. Some of the legless are eating on the floor next to the table. Jamal leans over to Salim.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (glancing at them)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Salim, Latika, Jamal and a group of children are standing in a line singing a doha- ancient lyrics set to music. Maman is leading the singing, walking up and down the line listening to each one individually. He stops at one small boy, Arvind, and listens. Nods his head, pleased, and continues down the line until he stops in front of Jamal. Holds up his hand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jamal starts singing again. He has the sweetest of voices. Untrained but pure. Maman smiles, ruffles Jamal's hair, impressed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A group of children are sitting in the jumble of concrete under a motorway flyover. Cars surround them, bumper to bumper. Latika and Jamal are playing an improvised hopscotch on concrete slabs. They are giggling, bumping into each other, tickling, laughing. Salim and Punnoose are sitting together, smoking. Salim is staring hard at Jamal and Latika until Punnoose grunts, a sign for Salim to clap his hands.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He laughs and walks over to Latika.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Surrounded by beer bottles, Punnoose is slumped asleep by the kitchen door. Latika edges past, avoids the cook sleeping under the table and goes to a shelf laden with vegetables. She pulls down a bunch of chillies still on the vine, strips a few off and tip-toes out with them. 59   INT. ORPHANAGE. DORMITORY. NIGHT.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sleeping children, three or four to a mattress on the floor. Latika tip-toes around the mattresses. She pauses over one in particular where we see Salim, asleep. She carefully pulls up the sheet, delves underneath. Pleasant dreams cross Salim's sleeping face for a second. Then suddenly, he is bolt upright and screaming. He charges around the room clutching his genitals in agony.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He sprints out of the room, wailing. 60   INT. ORPHANAGE. SHOWERS. NIGHT.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The lights are on and two dozen children are screaming with laughter as Salim stands under the make-shift shower directing the water down his pants to his burning genitals, his face a picture of agony. Latika wipes crushed chillies from her hands.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In a shack, Arvind is singing one of Surdas' bhajans in front of Maman and an old man who by his ragged appearance must be a villager. Punnoose and Salim sit behind Arvind.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Utterly bemused, Salim nevertheless helps Punnoose lay Arvind on the table. The villager takes hold of Arvind's eyelid and pulls it open. He brings the spoon close. Suddenly, Salim is being sick in the corner of the shack. By the time he has turned back, the villager is wiping the spoon on a blood-soaked rag.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All the children are asleep apart from Jamal who is crouched underneath a couple of wash-basins. (CONTINUED)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He is talking through a plate-sized hole in the crumbling masonry. Latika's eyes can be seen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Salim and Jamal walk along the path, Jamal humming happily. Salim checks behind him, sees Punnoose following.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (conversationally)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Salim guides Jamal into the shack where Maman and the Villager are waiting. Maman smiles. Punnoose slips in behind Salim.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shrugs)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Outside, a giggle. Latika is peering through a gap in the wall.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (simply)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Inspector is eying Jamal, weighing it all up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shrugging)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shakes his head)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Salim and Jamal are sitting on top of the train. Jamal is staring blankly down the track.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The ancient train is huffing slowly up an incline. A middle class Indian couple with their three children are sitting at a table, their breakfast spread before them. Into this domestic scene, unseen by them comes Jamal. Upside down and still outside the train, he is clearly being dangled by his ankles from the train roof. He gives a few, silent directional signs to Salim who manoeuvres him across, dips his hand into the open window, snatches a chapatti and signals franticly to be hoisted up. The family continue to eat, unperturbed. Then Jamal appears again. This time one of the children spots him. Despite Jamal giving her a friendly wave, she yelps. The father of the group grabs Jamal's hand which has just snatched a samosa. There is a tussle, Salim holding onto Jamal's legs, the father holding onto Jamal's arms and Jamal in the middle, shouting. Salim is losing the battle and his footing. He stumbles and the pair of them fall from the train, rolling and tumbling down an embankment in slow-motion. Interspersed with the seemingly endless tumble are images of Jamal and Salim on top of different trains- - huddled together against the freezing rain... - surfing the wind at the front of the train... - admiring the distant Himalaya....
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Groggily, Jamal sits up and groans. Somehow in the tumble, he has been transformed into a twelve year-old. And Salim a strong fourteen year-old. Through the haze of pain and dust, Jamal sees something glinting in the distance- something impossibly beautiful.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jamal and Salim wander under the great dome of the Taj Mahal. Two tiny slum kids dwarfed by this massive monument to love. It is a moment of genuine wonderment for them. Then a tour guide bustles nearby, tourists flowing behind him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jamal notices that he is standing next to a sign advertising guided tours of the Taj.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (suspicious)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nodding sagely)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shrugging)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Montage of Jamal authoritatively showing tourists around the Taj Mahal.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...and abandons the woman with a polite bow, charging for safety as two Police Officers race towards him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jamal stands a Tourist on a wall and positions his hands to create the optical illusion that he is dangling the Taj from his fingers. Takes a photo for the Tourist. Behind the Tourist, Salim and a boy called Shankar pick up the Tourist's shoes and saunter casually across the grass.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: By the side of a busy market street Salim stands next to a row of stolen shoes. Sneakers, court shoes, sandals, high heels...he is busy bartering with a man over a pair whilst Jamal tries to shout up business.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hectares of drying clothes by the side of the river. Spectacular squares of red, saffron, white. Not far away from the dhobi ghat, there is a makeshift slum- camp where Salim and a gang of children are sitting, smoking. Jamal joins them, hands over a wad of rupees to Salim. Salim counts the cash, hands half to Shankar and slaps Jamal so hard on the back that he nearly falls over.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jamal gets out of a new Mercedes driven by an Indian Man. A middle-aged American couple also get out. Jamal points them down a lane which opens out on India's largest dhobi where hundreds of women are beating clothes on stone slabs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A battered Jamal limps along the river bank towards the Taj. He stops, bathes his swollen face in the river. Then looks up. Strange lights appear to emanate from the base of the monument. And then strange sounds. 82   EXT. TAJ MAHAL. NIGHT.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jamal climbs   a crumbling   wall and is confronted with an opera taking   place right   under the dome. Gluck's Orfeo ed Euridice.   Hundreds of   India's smartest professionals are watching   from banked   seating on a scaffolding frame. 83   EXT. STANDS. NIGHT.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jamal and a couple of street kids slip under the scaffolding supporting the banked seats. The street kids are trying to reach the hand-bags of the women above them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (hissing)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jamal starts, makes to run, but the woman who spoke holds out a cigarette. A Canadian back-packer is sitting, staring at the singers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shrugging)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Salim, Shankar, Jamal and the Taj Gang are gathered around a campfire. All of them wear extraordinary foot- wear of one form or another, from elaborate high heels to walking boots five sizes too large. A home-made hooka pipe is being passed around the fire. The eyes of the children have long since stopped focussing. Salim is sporting a Mercedes Benz badge on a chain around his neck. Behind him, Jamal appears, his face swollen. He takes off his fake Guide's Badge and throws it in the fire.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Prem leans back in his chair.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Prem leans over and tears up the cheque. There is a sigh of disappointment from the audience, a look of confusion on Jamal's face.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Inspector pulls out a note from his wallet. Glances at it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: From a thousand feet in the sky, looking down on the limitless megatropolis of Mumbai. Half-built sky- scrapers, slums, factories, roads, trains.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ..who is staring through a wire fence at the construction site.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jamal asks a group of stall-holders on the slum main street. They shrug, aren't interested. The camera pulls up and up until Jamal is nothing but a dot wandering the maze of lanes, railways and highways, one among endless millions of people.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jamal wanders up to the rickshaw drivers parked outside the hotel. He stops and asks a question. The drivers shake their heads. Jamal continues up the steps towards a door, exhausted face and grubby clothes walking straight towards camera. He goes through the door and immediately.... 93   INT. HOTEL. FOYER. DAY.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ....is, without breaking step in a slightly grubby white uniform. He walks across the echoing, marble floor of a struggling four-star hotel, goes through double doors.... 94   INT. HOTEL CORRIDOR. DAY.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...into a corridor that is devoid of carpet, paint- anything except a phone on the bare wall and a stool. The phone is ringing. Jamal sits on the stool and answers the phone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...to a cramped kitchen with definite hygiene problems. The cooks are playing carom on the table while under it Salim is dozing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (impersonating Ram)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jamal is dodging the traffic at a busy junction. He moves around the beggars who are working the cars. Then he hears singing. He looks around, suddenly panicked. It is a siren song drawing him across the road, not even noticing that he is narrowly run down by a couple of cars, to a traffic island underneath a flyover. He turns a corner and there is the singer, leaning up against one of the struts of the flyover. Arvind. Older now, just like Jamal, a fourteen year-old boy. But eye- less. Jamal freezes. He approaches Arvind and waits until he has finished singing. Despite his eyeless sockets, Arvind appears to know somebody is there. He turns and bows low, putting his hands together.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jamal gets a couple of notes out of his pocket and puts them into Arvind's outstretched hand. He feels the notes with his fingers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He stops. Suspects.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (surprised)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dark, crowded streets. Gangs of women stand outside the doorways or lean out of upstairs windows. They are garishly-dressed prostitutes varying in age from 13 to 60. Men wander past, eying the possibilities, exchanging lewd comments with them. Among the hordes on the pavement are Jamal and Salim. They pass doorway after doorway of narrow rooms where prostitutes wait for customers. Jamal and Salim stop at each group of women, Salim taking the lead, clearly asking them something, as the women either shrug or offer them something lewd- judging by the laughter that follows. But one woman in a narrow doorway points down the street. Jamal has to drag a reluctant Salim away from the group. 98   INT. BROTHEL. NIGHT.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They go into one of the tiny houses. Loud Filmi music comes from upstairs. They are confronted by a woman in her fifties watching tv. She is less than interested.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Happy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You got what you wanted, didn't you? So, let's celebrate.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. Let's celebrate.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: While we can.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Service!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Reception!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We want a room, boy. Executive Class with smoking. Third floor with balcony.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sea-facing, yaar.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Have the bags brought up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Latika? Salim?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Room service!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: here. I want a bottle of Johnny Walker Red Label, beer, wine-
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: - chicken.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah! Chicken....
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What kind of chicken?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (also dreaming) Tikka Masala. With roti-
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Naan, chutney, dal-
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: - aloo gobi, rice-
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (eventually)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Dave is watching the screen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...if you want a chance to be a contestant on Who Wants To Be A Millionaire, dial the number now. Dave dives for the doorway and waves. 120   INT. CALL CENTRE. UK FLOOR. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly all the operators are dialling. Almost simultaneously, twenty or so voices say.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd like to be a contestant on Who Wants to be a Millionaire. Most of the Operators- including the man next to Jamal- suddenly lose their tension.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bloody bastard. I never get it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have to dial when Prem says "if". "If you want the chance to be a contestant on Who Wants To Be A Millionaire..." That's when they open the lines. The Operator looks at him. Jamal shrugs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's what Anjum in Technical says. He put the system in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So why don't you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello? Hello? Have I been transferred again, for God's sake? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 120   CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jamal freezes with fear. The head-set speaks again with its broad Scottish accent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello? Jesus, God, will somebody talk to me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello, Mrs... He stares at the computer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Mackintosh from King Gussie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's Kingussie, love. Pronounced Kinoosie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kinoosie?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So where are you from? Abroad, I bet. China or somewhere. What good is-
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - just down the road from your house, Mrs Mackintosh. Next to the loch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh aye? Which loch? Jamal searches desperately around, spots a picture of Big Ben.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Loch Big- Loch Ben. Next door to Detective Taggart's flat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Loch Ben? Och, no, hen, that's one of the wee ones up in the Highlands. You're all the way up there? But I bet it rains, eh, hen?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Indeed yes, Mrs Mackintosh. I have to wade through a metre of water every morning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No! (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 120   CONTINUED: (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, yes, Mrs Mackintosh. In my kilt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Och, no, hen. Jamal puts his feet on the desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's alright once I've had my porridge, my haggis and a few Scotch whiskies- and the monsoon's nearly over, so-
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - and what monsoon would that be? I'd like to speak to your supervisor, son.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't think that's a good idea. He is a very important man, Mrs Mackintosh-
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - get me the supervisor on this line now-
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - and he doesn't like bloody time wasters. Jamal panics, presses the button he saw the Manager press earlier. The screen goes blank, then reboots itself. Jamal looks around. Where the hell is Dave? On the screen, Jamal is faced with the question: "what name do you require?" He looks around again, and then with one finger types in the word "Latika". He presses enter. Hundred upon hundred of Latikas with their surnames and phone numbers scroll down the page. He erases her name and enters the name Salim K. Malik. Presses enter. Fifteen numbers come up. He stares at the numbers for a long time, then types it into his computer and presses dial.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Salim?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who wants to know? Do you know what bloody time it is? Clearly not Jamal's brother. Jamal cuts the line. Dials the next number. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 120   CONTINUED: (3)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Huh. Hello? Clearly not his Salim. He cuts the line. Dials again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello? Hello? Who is this? But Jamal can't speak.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey. Is someone screwing with me? Silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who is this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am calling from XL 5 Communications Sir. As a valued customer, we are offering you a free upgrade with our `friends and- Jamal's voice peters out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Family.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jamal? Is that you? Brother? Where are you, man?...I thought you were dead or something...we had to go, Jamal. Maman's guys. They were searching the hotel...Jamal, say something. Please. There is another long silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello, Salim. 121   INT. STUDIO. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ever been to Cambridge?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ever been to the circus? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 121   CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. And I've never been to UK before. But I'll still have a go. Gasps and laughter from the audience. Jamal laughs and shrugs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why not? Prem grips his heart theatrically.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can someone call me an ambulance? 122   INT. CALL CENTRE. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A flash of a sign post reading `Oxford Circus', pointing down one of the aisles. The banner above that section of the warehouse reads `London'.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Jamal hurrying down another `Kings Parade' carrying glasses of tea. He glances up to see a large banner that says `Cambridge'. CUT TO: Jamal comes back up an aisle named `Broad Street'. An Operator on the adjacent `The High' clicks his fingers for another cup. Jamal hurries under the sign marked `Oxford'. CUT TO: The signposts of the aisles come faster and faster `Pembroke Street', `Trafalgar Square', `East India Dock' and finally `Cambridge Circus'.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So, Jamal.... 123   INT. STUDIO. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jamal is sweating, his face scrunched up in thought.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't remember.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can't remember. Does that mean you did know? Once? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 123   CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't think it's Oxford.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Based on your extensive travelling, right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, Oxford has Broad Street, Saint Aldates, Turl Street, Queen Street, The High and Magdalene Bridge- which is pronounced Maudlin, so- He stops as he hears the surprised laughter of the audience.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought you hadn't been to UK.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, I haven't. And it's not Leeds, because that's Elland Road, Kirkgate Market, Commercial Street, St Peter's-
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - what might it be then, Jamal?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I don't think it's Cambridge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cambridge Circus is not in Cambridge? Dare I ask why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Too obvious. There's definitely an Oxford Circus in London, and there's a rowing race between Oxford and Cambridge so there's probably a Cambridge Circus too. I'll go for D) London.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's the logic that's got him this far, Ladies and Gentlemen. Who are we to argue? So. Jamal. D. Apka final jawab?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If the Gods are with me...Final answer. D. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 123   CONTINUED: (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The lights dim, the music swells as Prem pushes the button on his computer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Computer-ji, D lock kiya-jaye. More portentous music.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's been a rollercoaster ride all the way, a pleasure to have you on the show, my friend, but I'm sorry to say that you're....incredibly, absolutely right! Huge cheers and applause. Even Jamal laughs at this. He cannot quite believe it himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ladies and Gentlemen, Jamal Malik, the man with two and a half million rupees! More applause. Prem hands him a cheque. Jamal looks at it. Laughs again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A few hours ago, you were fetching tea for the phone- wallahs. Now you are richer than they ever will ever be. What a player, Ladies and Gentleman! What a player. The lights dim, the music swells. Prem consults his computer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For five million rupees, my friend: who invented the revolver? Was it A) Samuel Colt, B) Bruce Browning, C Dan Wesson or D) James Revolver? Dramatic pause. 124   INT. HOTEL. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A flash of Salim shooting Maman. Another flash of Salim in the doorway, holding the pistol up to Jamal's head. 125   INT. STUDIO. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A). Samuel Colt. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 125    CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jamal nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The music swells again. Prem presses his computer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He holds out his hand. Jamal hands him back the cheque. He tears the cheque in two.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cheers and applause from the audience. 125A   INT. INSPECTOR'S OFFICE. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The audience laugh. Prem is momentarily flustered.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The digital clocks show five fifteen. Shoving the descending river of people out of his way, the seventeen year-old Jamal is forging a path up steps that cross the platforms. He pushes to the middle of the footbridge and leans out on the side railings. He scans the sea of people, desperately. Then he sees her: the eighteen year-old Latika, heart-stoppingly beautiful, over the other side of the station. A world away. She is scanning the crowd, as wired as he is.

direction.raw_text: But though he is screaming her name, his voice is swallowed by the noise around him. Then he sees two thuggish-looking men also fighting a way towards her. (CONTINUED)

She sees them, starts running, is lost in the crowd. Jamal runs off along the platform after Latika.

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The line goes dead in Latika's hand. She stares down at the phone. The bemused family are still eying her like an alien. She smiles at them and goes out. The traffic on the road is still grid-locked. She starts walking, faster and faster. Then she breaks into a run. 192   INT. JAVED'S SAFE-HOUSE. BATHROOM. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (genuinely puzzled)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A small tv in the bathroom. Salim smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Salim! Teri ma ki chute! Salim! Javed is banging on the door. Salim gets up from where he has been praying. He climbs into the bath which is full of bank notes and lies down amongst the money. He reaches across for the pistol and picks it up. Smiles slightly as Javed smashes down the door, pulls the trigger and shoots Javed. He falls onto the floor, dead. But the Thug right behind him shoots Salim in the chest. He lies back in the bath, the faintest trace of a smile on his face as he stares at the pictures of Jamal on the tv.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: God is good. Salim dies. 193   INT. STUDIO. BACKSTAGE. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Prem and Jamal are being posed by photographers. A giant-sized cheque for twenty million rupees is manhandled onto the floor by the Floor Manager and an Assistant amidst much cheering and laughter. Jamal is snapped next to a scowling Prem. The Inspector appears next to them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just one more thing left, Sir. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 193   CONTINUED:                                                   193 Prem smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Finally, huh?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you'd like to come with me. He takes Jamal by the arm, leads him backstage. 194   INT/EXT. POLICE JEEP. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jamal sits silent in the back seat next to the Inspector as he drives through the traffic. Then:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Truth alone triumphs? I should have known better. The Inspector stops the jeep. Unlocks the handcuffs. Holds the back door open for Jamal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thought you might need a lift, Sir. He nods towards the outside world. Dazed, Jamal gets out. 195   EXT. CHHATRAPATI SHIVAJI TERMINUS. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jamal finds himself    gazing up     at VT station. Slowly, he wanders inside. The    Inspector     takes the contents of the file and tears them    slowly in     half. Lets the pieces fall on the ground.    Gets back     in the jeep and drives away. 196   OMITTED                                                      196 197   INT. CHHATRAPATI SHIVAJI TERMINUS. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: station is awash with the evening commute. Thousands of people crowd the platforms, jostling the only still figure who is sitting at the base of the statue of Frederick Stevens. Jamal. Then there is a gap in the wall of bodies that swirls around him. Jamal gets to his feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Latika? Then she is gone in the melee again. Only to reappear. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 197   CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jamal? Jamal forces himself through the people. Nothing will stop him. Latika too is shoving them aside until they are face-to-face. They stop, look at each other, hold each other's hands tight. The whole station seems frozen, the only movement from a thousand bodies being Jamal and Latika.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought we would meet again only in death. He shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I knew you'd be watching. Jamal puts his hand on Latika's chin, turns her head gently so that she is facing him. He sees the knife scars on her cheek for the first time. She tries to turn her head, but he won't let her. Runs his hand slowly down the scar. Rests his hand there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is our destiny. He gently kisses the scarred cheek.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is our destiny. The camera pulls back and back, rising above the station. The music starts and the frozen station comes alive, two thousand kurta-clad men and saree-clad women dancing in and out and on top of the trains, an unbound celebration of hope and humanity that has at its centre, Jamal and Latika.
direction.name: direction
